name: Multi-Perspective Onboarding Setup
description: This use case covers the collaborative configuration of ALFRED for an older adult by diverse caregivers—both formal and informal—with differing priorities and privacy preferences, ensuring the system accommodates varied user needs and operational contexts at initial setup.
scenario:
Olivia, recently retired and quite wary of technology, sat stiffly in her living room as Mike Johnson, the registered nurse, set up the ALFRED device on her tablet. Mike was efficient and focused, determined to get the health monitoring features running smoothly. He quickly connected Olivia’s wearable sensors, explaining their clinical importance without much patience for Olivia’s privacy concerns. “These sensors will help me track your vitals so I can intervene if anything serious happens,” he said, somewhat briskly, ignoring Olivia’s repeated insistence that her data remain private and not be shared with anyone outside immediate medical necessity.

Meanwhile, Sarah Thompson, Olivia’s informal caregiver, dialed in remotely to join the setup. Sarah’s approach was more nurturing and flexible; she wanted Olivia to feel comfortable and engaged, hoping to activate social features that might help combat her isolation. She gently suggested enabling video calls with family and some light cognitive games, but Olivia bristled at the idea, firmly rejecting anything she deemed “challenging” or intrusive. Sarah tried to explain how these features could be helpful, but Olivia’s mistrust of unsolicited notifications and her desire to keep all communications formal and minimal made the conversation tense. Sarah also pushed for some data-sharing settings to keep her informed about Olivia’s wellbeing, but Olivia flatly refused, demanding that no one besides herself see her information.

Mike, frustrated by the delays and the extra steps needed to respect Olivia’s strict privacy rules, insisted on prioritizing clinical access, stating that health data must be readily available during his shifts, even if Olivia objected. Sarah, however, advocated for more balanced consent controls, emphasizing Olivia’s right to control who sees what. Mike’s clinical mindset clashed with Sarah’s holistic care values, causing a palpable strain as they negotiated permissions in real time.

Olivia, overwhelmed by the conflicting voices and the complexity of the system, finally asked ALFRED to limit all notifications and block any app installations without her explicit permission. She preferred to keep the interaction minimal—just push-to-talk commands when she needed help, no detailed explanations of features, no games, no social nudges. Mike reluctantly accepted, focusing on configuring the system to suppress non-critical alerts during work hours, while Sarah promised to support Olivia’s preferences and remain available for informal check-ins.

The setup ended as a compromise rather than a consensus: ALFRED would provide robust health monitoring accessible to Mike during clinical hours, respect Olivia’s strict privacy wishes, and allow Sarah to maintain connection without overwhelming her with notifications or forced social interactions. The tension between clinical efficiency, emotional support, and personal autonomy remained palpable, setting the stage for a delicate balance in their ongoing care relationship.
